title: Hudson’s Bay Company agrees to be taken private after Richard Baker sweetens deal
text:
Hudson’s Bay Company today announced that it has agreed to be taken private by a shareholders’ group led by HBC chairman Richard Baker at $10.30 per share.

The price is 9% higher than $9.45 per share offer from the group in June and represents a 62% premium of HBC’s closing price on June 7.

The offer by the shareholders’ group, which owns about 57 per of HBC shares, was recommended by an independent special committee of the board which also looked at other options including the status quo. The board is recommending that minority shareholders vote in favour of the deal.

Hudson’s Bay Co. has tried everything from cutting costs to selling off assets, but nothing had halted its stock’s decline when Baker teamed up with investors, including Rhone Capital and WeWork Property Advisors, to make the offer in June.

“We believe that improving HBC’s performance will require significant time and patient long-term capital that is better suited in a private company context without the emphasis on short-term results and returns,” Baker said in a statement in June.

Activist investor Land & Buildings Investment Management, which has pushed for change at the iconic retailer, dismissed the group’s original bid as “woefully inadequate.”

More to come …
description: The price is 9% higher than $9.45 per share offer from the group in June, but minority shareholders still have to vote on deal
